</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:3px double #000000" valign=bottom width=107.067><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right>$ &nbsp;&nbsp;2,050,600</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">k)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Accounts Receivable and Concentrations of Credit Risk</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company grants credit to its customers in the normal course of business. Trade receivables are typically non-interest bearing and are initially recorded at cost. Sales to the Company&#146;s recurring customers are generally made on open account terms. Past due status of customer accounts is determined based on how recently payments have been received in relation to payment terms granted. Credit is generally extended based upon an evaluation of each customer&#146;s financial condition, with terms consistent in the industry and no collateral required. Losses from credit sales are provided for in the financial statements and consistently have been within the allowance provided. The allowance is an estimate of the uncollectibility of accounts receivable based on an evaluation of specific customer risks along with additional reserves based on historical and probable bad debt experience. Amounts are written off against the allowance in the period the Company determines that the receivable is uncollectible. The Company has not recorded an allowance for doubtful accounts against its accounts receivable in each of the years ended June 30, 2011 or June 30, 2010. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Currency Risk</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company holds cash of $276,225 (2010 $858,156) in Canadian dollars exposing it to a foreign currency exchange risk. During the year ended June 30, 2011 the Company realized a foreign exchange gain of $37,919 (2010: $(30,615)) as a result of the Company holding cash in Canadian dollars.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>34</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>June 30, 2011 and 2010</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:69px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 2</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Significant Accounting Policies</U> &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">l)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Revenue Recognition</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) Staff Accounting Bulletin 104, &#147;Revenue Recognition&#148;, which requires that: (i) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (ii) delivery has occurred, (iii) the sales price is fixed and determinable, and (iv) collectability is reasonably assured. The Company recognizes revenue when the building supplies have been shipped. The Company has not disclosed revenues by individual products and services as it impracticable to do.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company also recognizes revenue on a &#147;bill-and-hold&#148; basis in accordance with the authoritative guidance. Under the Company&#146;s &#147;bill-and-hold&#148; arrangements, at the request of the customer, finished inventory is segregated for future delivery at the customer&#146;s discretion. &nbsp;Title and risk of loss of the inventory has passed to the customer upon transfer at which time, the Company receives payment from the customer and recognizes revenue thereon<FONT style="font-family:Georgia,Times New Roman">. </FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial; float:left">m)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial"><U>Income Taxes</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">The Company follows the liability method of accounting for income taxes. &nbsp;Under this method, current income taxes are recognized for the estimated income taxes payable for the current year. &nbsp;Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognized in the current year for temporary differences between the tax and accounting basis of assets and liabilities as well as for the benefit of losses available to be carried forward to future years for tax purposes. &nbsp;Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are measured using tax rates and laws expected to apply in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. &nbsp;The effect of a change in tax rates on deferred income tax assets and liabilities is recognized in operations in the year of change. &nbsp;A valuation allowance is recorded when it is &#147;more likely-than-not&#148; that a deferred tax asset will not be realized.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial; float:left">n)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial"><U>Stock-based Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">The Company accounts for all stock-based payments and awards under the fair value based method.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">Stock-based payments to non-employees are measured at the fair value of the consideration received, or the fair value of the equity instruments issued, or liabilities incurred, whichever is more reliably measurable. The fair value of stock-based payments to non-employees is periodically re-measured until the counterparty performance is complete, and any change therein is recognized over the vesting period of the award and in the same manner as if the Company had paid cash instead of paying with or using equity based instruments. The cost of the stock-based payments to non-employees that is fully vested and non-forfeitable as at the grant date is measured and recognized at that date. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">The Company accounts for the granting of share purchase options to employees using the fair value method whereby all awards to employees will be recorded at fair value on the date of the grant. &nbsp;The fair value of all share purchase options are expensed over their vesting period with a corresponding increase to additional capital surplus. &nbsp;Upon exercise of share purchase options, the consideration paid by the option holder, together with the amount previously recognized in additional paid-in capital is recorded as an increase to share capital. Share purchase options granted to employees are accounted for as liabilities when they contain conditions or other features that are indexed to other than a market, performance or service condition. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>35</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>June 30, 2011 and 2010</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 2</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Significant Accounting Policies</U> &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company uses the binomial option pricing model to determine the fair value of all stock-based awards classified as liabilities and the Black-Scholes option pricing model to determine the fair value of stock option awards classified as equity. &nbsp;Option pricing models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, including expected price volatility. Changes in these assumptions could materially affect the fair value estimate.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">o)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Derivative Liabilities</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Free standing warrants and share purchase options are classified as liabilities and are measured at fair value. These instruments are adjusted to reflect fair value at each period end. Any increase or decrease in the fair value are recorded in results of operations as change in fair value of derivative liabilities except for changes in the fair value of employee stock options classified as liabilities being recorded in wages and management fees.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">In determining the appropriate fair value, the Company used the binomial pricing model.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial; float:left">p)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial"><U>Recent Accounting Pronouncements</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">In October 2009, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update (&#147;ASU&#148;) No.&nbsp;2009-13, <I>Multiple-Deliverable Revenue Arrangements</I>. The new standard changes the requirements for establishing separate units of accounting in a multiple element arrangement and requires the allocation of arrangement consideration to each deliverable based on the relative selling price. The selling price for each deliverable is based on vendor-specific objective evidence (&#147;VSOE&#148;) if available, third-party evidence if VSOE is not available, or estimated selling price if neither VSOE or third-party evidence is available. ASU 2009-13 is effective for revenue arrangements entered into in fiscal years beginning on or after June&nbsp;15, 2010. The adoption of this standard did not have a material effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">In January 2010, the FASB issued ASU No.&nbsp;2010-06, <I>Improving Disclosures about Fair Value Measurements</I>, which requires additional disclosures about the amounts of and reasons for significant transfers in and out of Level&nbsp;1 and Level&nbsp;2 fair value measurements. This standard also clarifies existing disclosure requirements related to the level of disaggregation of fair value measurements for each class of assets and liabilities and disclosures about inputs and valuation techniques used to measure fair value for both recurring and non-recurring Level&nbsp;2 and Level&nbsp;3 measurements. Since this new accounting standard only required additional disclosure, the adoption of the standard in the first quarter of 2010 did not impact the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. Additionally, effective for annual periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2010 and interim periods within those fiscal years, this standard will require additional disclosure and require an entity to present disaggregated information about activity in Level&nbsp;3 fair value measurements on a gross basis, rather than one net amount.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">In April 2010, the FASB issued ASU No. 2010-13, &#147;<I>Compensation &#150; Stock Compensation,</I>&#148; or ASU 2010-13, which amends ASC Topic 718 to address the classification of an employee share-based payment award with an exercise price denominated in a currency of a market in which the underlying security trades. Specifically, an employee share-based payment award denominated in a currency of a market in which a substantial portion of the entity&#146;s equity securities trades should not be considered to contain a condition that is not a market, performance or service condition and therefore would not classify the award as a liability if it otherwise qualifies as equity. This update is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning on or after December 15, 2010. &nbsp;The Company has adopted this guidance effective July 1, 2011 at which time the fair value of the employee share purchase options previously classified as a liability was reclassified to additional paid-in capital.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>36</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">p)</P>

<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=259><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Assets under capital lease</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=102.667><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=102.667><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=102.667><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>

<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 4</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Property, Plant and Equipment &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">During the year ended June 30, 2011, the Company recorded depreciation expense of $272,105 (2010: $264,101) on its property, plant and equipment. This amount is included in cost of sales in the Statement of Operations</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Depreciation of assets under capital leases included in amortization expense for the year ended June 30, 2011 was $90,852 (2010: &nbsp;$90,852).</P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 6</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Warrant Liability</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">During the year ended June 30, 2010, the Company sold 15,000,000&nbsp;units at $ 0.10 CDN per unit for total proceeds of $1,482,974 ($1,500,000 CDN). Each unit consisted of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the holder to purchase an additional common share at $CDN 0.15 for a period of two years. Upon the adoption of the guidance in ASC 815-40-15 which became effective for the fiscal year that commenced July 1, 2009, the Company recorded the warrants issued as derivative liabilities due to their exercise price being denominated in a currency other than the Company&#146;s US dollar functional currency. </P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The warrant liability is accounted for at its respective fair values as follows:</P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 align=center><TR height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=294.667 /><TD width=102.667 /><TD width=112 /></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=294.667><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom width=102.667><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=right>2011</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom width=112><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=right>2010</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=294.667><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Beginning Fair Value </P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=102.667><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right>$ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2,010,000</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=112><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right>$ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=294.667><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Issuance of warrant liability</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=102.667><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=112><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right>1,083,000</P>

<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 6</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Warrant Liability &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><FONT style="background-color:#FFFFFF">The warrant liability will be revalued at the end of each reporting period with the change in fair value of the derivative liability recorded as a gain or loss in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statements of Operations. The fair value of the warrants will continue to be classified as a liability until such time as they are exercised, expire or there is an amendment to the respective agreements that renders these financial instruments to be no longer classified as a liability. </FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 9</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Common Stock</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">a)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Escrow:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">At June 30, 2011, there are 48,922 (2010 &#150; 48,922) common shares held in escrow by the Company&#146;s transfer agent, the release which is subject to the approval of the regulatory authorities. As at June 30, 2011, all of these shares held in escrow are issuable but the Company has yet to request their release. &nbsp;These shares have been included in the computation of net loss per share.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Commitments:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based Compensation Plan</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">In November 2005, the Company continued its rolling stock option plan (&#147;the 2005 Rolling Plan&#148;). &nbsp;The 2005 Rolling Plan provides for the granting of stock options to selected directors, officers, employees or consultants in an aggregate amount of up to 10% of the issued and outstanding common shares of the Company. &nbsp;Under the 2005 Rolling Plan, the granting of stock options, exercise prices and terms are determined by the Company's Board of Directors. Options granted to non-executive employees and consultants typically vest in stages over various periods of time while options granted to Directors and executive employees vest immediately upon their grant. The exercise price shall not be less than the Discounted Market Price, which is defined as the last closing price of the common shares before the date of the grant less an applicable discount, as allowed by the regulatory authorities. Options granted under the 2005 Rolling Plan may not exceed &nbsp;a term of 5 years unless the Company achieves classification as a &#147;Tier 1 &#147; issuer in accordance with the policies of the TSX, in which case, the options may be granted for a maximum term of 10 years. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>40</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>

<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>June 30, 2011 and 2010</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>

<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Commitments: - (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based Compensation Plan &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">A summary of the status of the Company&#146;s share purchase option plan as of June 30, 2011 and 2010 and changes during the years ending on those dates is presented below:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 align=center><TR height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=193.333 /><TD width=112 /><TD width=90.667 /><TD width=102.667 /></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=193.333><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=112><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=90.667><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>&nbsp;Weighted </P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>June 30, 2011 and 2010</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 9</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Common Stock &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Commitments: - (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based Compensation Plan &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Non-Employee Share Purchase Options</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">In accordance with the guidance of ASC 815-40-15, stock options granted to non-employees that are exercisable in Canadian dollars are required to be accounted for as derivative liabilities because they are considered not to be indexed to the Company&#146;s stock due to their exercise price being denominated in a currency other than the Company&#146;s US dollar functional currency. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The non-employee share purchase option liabilities are accounted for at their respective fair values and are summarized as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 align=center><TR height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=367 /><TD width=102.667 /><TD width=102.667 /></TR>

</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom width=102.667><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=right>2010</P>

</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><FONT style="background-color:#FFFFFF">The non-employee options are required to be re-valued with the change in fair value of the liability recorded as a gain or loss on the change of fair value of derivative liability and included in other items in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statements of Operations at the end of each reporting period. The fair value of the options will continue to be classified as a liability until such time as they are exercised, expire or there is an amendment to the respective agreements that renders these financial instruments to be no longer classified as a liability. </FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Employee Share Purchase Options</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Share options granted to employees that are exercisable in Canadian dollars are accounted for as liabilities because these option awards contain a condition that is other than a market, performance or service condition.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The share purchase option liabilities are accounted for at their respective fair values and are summarized as follows:</P>

<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Common Stock &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>

<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based Compensation Plan &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Employee Share Purchase Options &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><FONT style="background-color:#FFFFFF">The employee share options that are classified as liabilities are required to be revalued with the change in fair value of the liability included in Wages and Management fees in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statements of Operations at the end of each reporting period. The fair value of the options will continue to be classified as a liability until such time as they are exercised, expire or there is an amendment to the respective agreements that renders these financial instruments to be no longer classified as a liability. </FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 9</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Common Stock &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Commitments: - (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based Compensation Plan &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; padding-right:24px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>Warrants</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; padding-right:24px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>At June 30, 2011 and 2010, the following share purchase warrants were outstanding entitling the holder to purchase one common share for each warrant held as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 align=center><TR height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=86.667 /><TD width=112 /><TD width=118.667 /></TR>

</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company evaluates its valuation allowance requirements based on projected future operations. When circumstances change and this causes a change in management&#146;s judgment about the recoverability of future tax assets, the impact of the change on the valuation allowance is reflected in current income. As management of the Company does not currently believe that it is more likely than not that the Company will receive the benefit of this asset, a valuation allowance equal to the future tax asset has been established at both June 30, 2011 and June 30, 2010. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">As at June 30, 2011, the Company had estimated net operating loss carry-forwards available to reduce taxable income in future years, which were incurred in the United States and Canada as follows: </P>

<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>June 30, 2011 and 2010</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 12</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Income Taxes &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><I>Uncertain Tax Positions</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company makes an assessment of its income tax positions for all years subject to examination based upon an evaluation of the facts, circumstances and information available at the reporting date. &nbsp;For all tax positions where there is a more than 50% likelihood that a tax benefit will be sustained by a tax authority with full knowledge of all relevant information, the Company fully recognizes the tax position taken. &nbsp;For income tax positions where there is a 50% or less likelihood the tax benefit would be sustained, no tax benefit is recognized in the financial statements. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, various state and foreign jurisdictions. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s tax returns are subject to tax examinations by U.S. federal and state tax authorities, or examinations by foreign tax authorities until respective statute of limitation. &nbsp;The Company currently has no tax years under examination. The Company is subject to tax examinations by tax authorities for all taxation years commencing after 2004.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">At June 30, 2011, the Company does not have an accrual relating to uncertain tax positions. It is not anticipated that unrecognized tax benefits would significantly increase or decrease within 12 months of the reporting date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Provision has not been made for U.S. or additional foreign taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries. Such earnings have been and will continue to be reinvested but could become subject to additional tax if they were remitted as dividends, or were loaned to the Company affiliate. It is not practicable to determine the amount of additional tax, if any, that might be payable on the undistributed foreign earnings. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 13</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Segmented information and sales concentration</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company operates in one industry segment being the manufacturing and marketing of fire resistant building materials. Substantially all of the Company&#146;s revenues and long-term assets are located in the United States. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">During the year ended June 30, 2011, two customers accounted for 98% of total revenues (each representing 72% and 26% respectively) (2010: two customers accounted for 87% of total revenues (each representing 71% and 16% respectively). &nbsp;The amounts receivable from each of these customers at June 30, 2011 is $Nil and $43,261 respectively (2010: $15,444 and $48,420 respectively). &nbsp;The loss of either of these customers or the curtailment of purchases by such customers could have material adverse effects on the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 14 </P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Interest and Other Income</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Interest and other income in 2010 includes an amount of $90,000 in respect of funds received from Pyrotite Corporation (&#147;Pyrotite&#148;) as final mediated settlement of a dispute over an agreement between Pyrotite and the Company to share revenues earned from the sale of products utilizing a fire retardant technology. In addition to the payment, Pyrotite agreed to convey all of its right, title and interest in the technology to the Company. </P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 15</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Contingencies</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">In the ordinary course of business, the Company is subject to potential warranty claims. Accruals are made to offset potential claims where such liabilities can be reasonably estimated. Although it is possible that liabilities may be incurred in instances for which no accruals have been made, the Company does not believe that the ultimate outcome of these matters will have a material impact on its consolidated financial position.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>46</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc305669996"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 9. &nbsp;CHANGES IN AND DISAGREEMENTS WITH ACCOUNTANTS ON ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">None</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc305669997"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 9A. &nbsp;CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B>(a) &nbsp;Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures</B> </P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>As required by Rule 13(a)-15 under the Exchange Act, in connection with this annual report on Form 10-K, under the direction of the Chief Executive Officer, the Company has evaluated its disclosure controls and procedures as of June 30, 2011, and has concluded the disclosure controls and procedures were ineffective as discussed in greater detail below. &nbsp;As of the date of this filing, the Company is still in the process of remediating such material weaknesses in its internal controls and procedures.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B>(b) &nbsp;Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining internal control over financial reporting, as such term is defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Our management evaluated, under the supervision and with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, the effectiveness of its internal control over financial reporting as of June 30, 2011.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Based on its evaluation under the framework in Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework, issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission, management with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting was not effective as of June 30, 2011, due to the existence of a significant deficiency constituting a material weakness, as described in greater detail below. &nbsp;A material weakness is a control deficiency, or combination of control deficiencies, such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected on a timely basis. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>In light of this material weakness, the Company performed additional post-closing procedures and analyses in order to prepare the consolidated financial statements included in this report. As a result of these procedures, the Company believes its consolidated financial statements included in this report present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position, results of operations and cash flows for the year ended June 30, 2011. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><I>Limitations on Effectiveness of Controls</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer does not expect that disclosure controls or internal control over financial reporting will prevent all errors and all fraud. A control system, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable, not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the control system are met. &nbsp;Further, the design of a control system must reflect the fact that there are resource constraints, and the benefits of controls must be considered relative to their costs. &nbsp;Because of the inherent limitations in all control systems, no evaluation of controls can provide absolute assurance that all control issues and instances of fraud, if any, within the company have been detected. &nbsp;These inherent limitations include the realities that judgments in decision-making can be faulty, and that breakdowns can occur because of a simple error or mistake. &nbsp;Additional controls can be circumvented by the individual acts of some persons, by collusion of two or more people, or by management override of the controls. &nbsp;The design of any system of controls also is based in part upon certain assumptions about the likelihood of future events, and there can be no assurance that any design will succeed in achieving its stated goals under all potential future conditions; over time, controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. &nbsp;Because of the inherent limitations in a cost-effective control system, misstatements due to error or fraud may occur and not be detected.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>47</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><I>Material Weaknesses Identified</I> &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>In connection with the preparation of the consolidated financial statements for the year ended June 30, 2011, management identified the following material weakness in internal control:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0><TR height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=32.133 /><TD width=618.667 /></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=32.133><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" width=618.667><P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Our company&#146;s accounting staff does not have sufficient technical accounting knowledge relating to accounting for income taxes and complex US GAAP matters. &nbsp;</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><I>Plan for Remediation of Material Weaknesses</I> </P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>We intend to take appropriate and reasonable steps to make the necessary improvements to remediate this deficiency as resources to do so become available. &nbsp;We intend to consider the results of our remediation efforts and related testing as part of our year-end 2012 assessment of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Such remediation would entail enhancing the training and oversight of the accounting personnel responsible for non-routine transactions involving complex accounting matters and engaging the services of an independent consultant with sufficient expertise in income tax and complex US GAAP matters to assist us in the preparation of our financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-48px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B>(c) &nbsp;Changes in Internal Controls</B> &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>There were no changes in the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting during the fourth quarter of our fiscal year ended June 30, 2011 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">None</P>

<A NAME="_Toc305670000"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERANCE</U></B></P>

<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The following table lists the names of the Directors and Executive Officers of the Company. &nbsp;The Directors have served in their respective capacities since their election and/or appointment and will serve until the next Annual Shareholders&#146; Meeting or until a successor is duly elected, unless the office is vacated in accordance with the Articles/By-Laws of the Company. &nbsp;The Executive Officers serve at the pleasure of the Board of Directors.</P>

<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-9.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Date of</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-9.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;First</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-9.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Election or</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-9.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Name &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Position &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Age &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Appointment</U></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><I>David J. Corcoran</I>, Administrator, Chief Financial Officer, and Director, is a Chartered Accountant and a member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in British Columbia, Canada, with over twenty-five years of experience in industry and commerce. &nbsp;Prior to 1976, Mr. Corcoran spent over five years gaining experience in marketing, sales and product distribution while he worked in sales with several major companies including Scott Paper and Bristol Myers. &nbsp;His career in accounting began in 1976 when he joined Touche Ross and Company. &nbsp;In 1979, he founded Corcoran and Company, Chartered Accountants. &nbsp;From 1979 to 1990, his firm secured a wide variety of business clients whom he advised regarding their management and business planning. &nbsp;In 1991, he joined the management of the Company on a full-time basis. &nbsp;Mr. Corcoran brings to the organization specific business experience in both sales and public finance. &nbsp;He has been an officer and director of the Company since it inception in 1986.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>49</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><I>Michael D. Huddy</I>, President/CEO and Director, joined the Company in February 1993 as President of the newly-formed US Subsidiary, Barrier Technology Corporation. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy was elected President/CEO of the Company and a Director in July 1994. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy had been in charge of marketing and sales of Blazeguard<FONT style="font-family:Symbol">&#226;</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Courier New"> with Citadel and Weyerhaeuser. &nbsp;He was part of Weyerhaeuser&#146;s research/development team established to develop the Blazeguard</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Symbol">&#226;</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Courier New"> product. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy brings sales, marketing and general management experience. &nbsp;He joined Weyerhaeuser&#146;s Architectural Products Group in 1988, after two years as General Manager of Weyerhaeuser&#146;s Northwest Hardwoods operations in Wisconsin. &nbsp;Before joining Weyerhaeuser, Dr. Huddy worked for Crown Zellerbach Corporation for seven years. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Biological Sciences with a minor in Chemistry from Lake Superior State College; a Masters of Science degree in Resource Administration; and a Ph.D. in Natural Resource Economics with a minor in Business Management from Michigan State University.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><I>Lindsey Nauen</I>, Corporate Secretary, received her MBA from the University of Minnesota in 1988. &nbsp;She also received a B.A. in psychology in 1971 and a M.A. in Library Science in 1974. &nbsp;For the last eleven years she has been the owner of Nauen Mobil Accounting, providing accounting and business consulting services to small businesses. &nbsp;In that capacity, she has been providing accounting services to the Company since 1999.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><I>Craig Roberts</I>, Director, is the Director Professional Services of Reed Construction Data, a division of Reed Business Information. &nbsp;Mr. Roberts was formerly a Senior Director of Ingenium Technologies.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><I>Victor A. Yates</I>, Director, is a self-employed businessman involved in real estate, construction of multi-family and commercial developments. &nbsp;He holds a degree in Real Estate Appraisal and is a Licensed Real Estate Agent. &nbsp;He 25 years experience in operating a variety of business ventures brings to the Board an entrepreneurial and construction and financial perspective.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>The Directors have served in their respective capacities since their election and/or appointment and will serve until the next Annual General Meeting or until a successor is duly elected, unless the office is vacated in accordance with the Articles/By-Laws of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>The Executive Officers serve at the pleasure of the Board of Directors with management service contracts but without term of office.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Despite the Company&#146;s Secretary/Administrator spending material portions of this time on businesses other than the Company, the Company believes that he devotes sufficient time to the Company to properly carry out his duties.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>No Director and/or Executive Officer has been the subject of any order, judgment, or decree of any governmental agency or administrator or of any court or competent jurisdiction, revoking or suspending for cause any license, permit or other authority of such person or of any corporation of which he is a Director and/or Executive Officer, to engage in the securities business or in the sale of a particular security or temporarily or permanently restraining or enjoining any such person or any corporation of which he is an officer or director from engaging in or continuing any conduct, practice, or employment in connection with the purchase or sale of securities, or convicting such person of any felony or misdemeanor involving a security or any aspect of the securities business or of theft or of any felony.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>There are no arrangements or understandings between any two or more Directors or Executive Officers, pursuant to which he was selected as a Director or Executive Officer. &nbsp;There are no family relationships between any two or more Directors or Executive Officers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>50</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Board of Director Practices</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>All directors hold office until the next meeting of the shareholders of the Company unless they resign or are removed in accordance with the Company&#146;s Articles. &nbsp;Officers are appointed to serve at the discretion of the Board of Directors. &nbsp;The Board of Directors and Committees of the Board schedule regular meetings over the course of the year.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The fundamental objective of the Board is to ensure that it operates in a fashion that maximizes shareholder value over the long term. &nbsp;The Board&#146;s duties and responsibilities are all carried out in a manner consistent with that fundamental objective. &nbsp;The principal duty and responsibility of the Board is to oversee the management and operations of the Company, with the day-to-day management of the business and affairs of the Company delegated by the Board to the CEO and other Executive Officers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Board&#146;s responsibilities include overseeing the conduct of the Company&#146;s business, providing leadership and direction to its management, and setting policies. &nbsp;Strategic direction for the Company is developed through the Board&#146;s annual planning process. &nbsp;Through this process, the Board adopts the operating plan for the coming year, and monitors management&#146;s progress relative to that plan through a regular reporting and review process.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Board has delegated to the President/Chief Executive Officer and the Executive Officers responsibility for the day-to-day management of the business of the Company. &nbsp;Matters of policy and issues outside the normal course of business are brought before the Board for its review and approval, along with all matters dictated by statute and legislation requiring Board review and approval. &nbsp;The President/CEO and the Executive Officers review the Company&#146;s progress in relation to the current operating plan at in-person Board meetings. &nbsp;The Board meets on a regular basis with and without management present. &nbsp;Financial, operational and strategic issues facing the Company are reviewed, monitored and approved at the Board meetings.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Compliance with Section 16(a) of the Exchange Act</U></B><B> &nbsp;</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Board of Directors, all Officers, and major shareholders of 10% or more of International Barrier Technology Inc. are in compliance with all reporting requirements of the exchange act. &nbsp;Craig Roberts, a director, late filed one Form 4 during Fiscal 2011, related to the grant of stock options replacing expired options.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Code of Ethics</U></B> &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has not adopted a written &#147;code of ethics&#148; that meets the new United States' Sarbanes-Oxley standards; the Board of Directors believes that existing Canadian standards and procedures is adequate for its purposes. &nbsp;The Company has not seen any need to adopt a written code of ethics on the basis that its corporate culture effectively deters wrongdoing and promotes honest and ethical conduct, full, fair and accurate, timely, and understandable disclosure in reports and documents, the compliance with applicable governmental laws, rules and regulations; the prompt internal reporting of violations of the code; and accountability for adherence to the code.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Corporate Governance</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Director Independence</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Pursuant to Item 407(a)(1)(ii) of Regulation S-K of the Securities Act, our Board of Directors has adopted standards for determining whether a director is independent from management. &nbsp;The Board reviews, consistent with the Company&#146;s corporate governance guidelines, whether a director has any material relationship with the Company that would impair the director&#146;s independent judgment. &nbsp;In summary, an independent director means a person other than an executive officer or employee or any other individual having a relationship which, in the opinion of our directors, would interfere with the exercise of independent judgment in carrying out the responsibilities of a director, and includes any director who accepts compensation from us exceeding $200,000 during any period of twelve consecutive months within the three past fiscal years. &nbsp;Owning shares of our common stock does not preclude a director from being </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>51</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>independent. &nbsp;In applying this definition, our board determined that Craig Roberts and Victor Yates are independent.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Our board adopted and applied the same definition of independent director to the members of our audit committee. &nbsp;In applying this definition, our board determined that Craig Roberts and Victor Yates qualify as an independent director for purposes of Section 10A(m)(3) of the Securities Exchange Act.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Board Meetings and Committees; Annual Meeting Attendance</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During Fiscal 2011, the Board of Directors held six regularly scheduled meetings, and six special and telephone meetings. &nbsp;For various reasons, Board members may not be able to attend a Board meeting; all Board members are provided information related to each of the agenda items before each meeting, and, therefore, can provide counsel outside the confines of regularly scheduled meetings. &nbsp;No director attended fewer than 75% of the aggregate of: (1) the total number of meetings of the Board of Directors, while he was a Director; and (2) the total number of meetings of committees of the Board of Directors on which the director served. &nbsp;Directors are encouraged to attend annual meetings of our stockholder; three of the directors physically attended the November 2010 annual shareholders meeting and one director attended via teleconference.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Nominating Committee and Compensation Committee</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company does not have a Nominating Committee. &nbsp;The entire Board of Directors is responsible for screening potential director candidates and recommending qualified candidates for nomination as members of the Board of Directors. In evaluating potential director candidates, the Board of Directors considers recommendations of potential candidates from incumbent directors, management and stockholders. &nbsp;Any recommendation submitted by a stockholder to the Board of Directors must include the same information concerning the potential candidate and the stockholder, and must be received in the time frame described herein for the Calendar 2011 Annual meeting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has a Compensation Committee. &nbsp;The committee consists of David Corcoran, Craig Roberts and Martin Lizt. &nbsp;The committee is responsible for the compensation of the Company&#146;s executive officers and to administer all incentive compensation plans and equity-based plans of the Company, including the plans under which Company securities may be acquired by directors, executive officers, employees and consultants.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Audit Committee</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has an Audit Committee, which recommends to the Board of Directors the engagement of the independent auditors of the Company and reviews with the independent auditors the scope and results of the Company&#146;s audits, the Company&#146;s internal accounting controls, and the professional services furnished by the independent auditors to the Company. &nbsp;The current members of the Audit Committee are: David Corcoran, Craig Roberts (independent) and Victor Yates (independent). &nbsp;The Audit Committee met monthly in Fiscal 2011 and has met three times during Fiscal 2012-to-date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company does not have an &#147;audit committee financial expert&#148; serving on its Audit Committee. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s Audit Committee consists of two independent directors and the Company&#146;s Chief Financial Officer, all of whom are both financially literate and very knowledgeable about the Company&#146;s affairs. &nbsp;Because the Company&#146;s structure and operations are straightforward, the Company does not find it necessary to augment its Board with a financial expert.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>52</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The audit committee has:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>a. reviewed and discussed the audited financial statements with management;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>b. discussed with the independent auditors the matters required to be discussed by the statement on Auditing Standards No. 61, as amended (AICPA, <I>Professional Standards </I>, Vol. 1. AU section 380), as adopted by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board in Rule 3200T;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>c. received the written disclosures and the letter from the independent accountants required by as adopted by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board in Rule 3526, and has discussed with the independent accountant the independent accountant's independence; and</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>d. recommended to the board of directors that the audited financial statements be included in the Company's annual report on Form 10&#150;K for the last fiscal year for filing with the SEC.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Audit Committee recommends to the Board of Directors the engagement of the independent auditors of the Company and reviews with the independent auditors the scope and results of the Company&#146;s audits, the Company&#146;s internal accounting controls, and the professional services furnished by the independent auditors to the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The audit committee is directly responsible for the appointment, compensation and oversight of auditors; the audit committee has in place procedures for receiving complaints and concerns about accounting and auditing matters; and has the authority and the funding to engage independent counsel and other outside advisors.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Audit Committee may delegate to one or more designated members of the Audit Committee the authority to grant pre-approvals required by this policy and procedure. &nbsp;The decisions of any Audit Committee member to whom authority is delegated to pre-approve a service shall be presented to the full Audit Committee at its next scheduled meeting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>In accordance with the requirements of the US Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and rules issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission, we introduced a procedure for the review and pre-approval of any services performed by BDO Dunwoody including audit services, audit related services, tax services and other services. &nbsp;The procedure requires that all proposed engagements of DBO Dunwoody LLP for audit and permitted non-audit services are submitted to the audit committee for approval prior to the beginning of any such services.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Shareholder Communications With the Board</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Historically, the Company has adopted an informal process for stockholder communications with the Board by providing an email address and toll-free phone number available on the website: www.intlbarrier.com. &nbsp;Every effort has been made to ensure that the views of stockholders are heard by the Board, or individual directors as applicable, and that appropriate responses are provided to the stockholder in a timely manner. &nbsp;Stockholders wishing to communicate at any time with the Board of Directors, or a specific member of the Board, may do so by writing the Board or a specific member of the Board by delivering correspondence in person or by mail to: The Board of Directors, c/o Lindsey Nauen, Corporate Secretary, 510 4th Street North, Watkins, Minnesota &nbsp;55389. &nbsp;Communication(s) directed to the Board or a specific Board member will be relayed unopened to the intended Board member(s).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Further, Directors&#146; attendance at Annual Meetings can provide shareholders with an opportunity to communicate with Directors about issues affecting the Company. &nbsp;The Company does not have a policy regarding director attendance, but all Directors are encouraged to attend the Annual Meeting of Shareholders. &nbsp;All of our directors attended our Annual Meeting in November 2010.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>53</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc305670001"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 11. &nbsp;EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Director Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company compensates Directors for their service in their capacity as Directors, $750 per physical meeting. &nbsp;Directors are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable travel and other out-of-pocket expenses incurred in connection with attendance at meetings of the Board of Directors. &nbsp;The Board of Directors may award special remuneration to any Director undertaking any special services on behalf of the Company other than services ordinarily required of a Director. &nbsp;During Fiscal 2011/2010/2009, Directors were paid $17,250, $13,500, and $6,795 for attending meetings, respectively. During the year ended June 30, 2011, Craig Roberts was granted 250,000 common share purchase options. &nbsp;The options granted to the director are exercisable in Canadian currency that requires them to be recorded as liabilities due to their exercise price being denominated in a currency other than the functional currency of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Executive Officer Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The following table sets forth the summary of compensation earned during Fiscal 2010 and Fiscal 2011 by the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer and its other named Executive Officers. &nbsp;The following table excludes Directors&#146; Fees paid to Executive Officers who are also Directors; refer to Table No. 6.</P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Stock Options</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company grants stock options to Directors, Executive Officers and employees/consultants; refer to ITEM #11, &#147;Stock Options&#148; and Tables 5/6/7/8/9.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Stock Options Granted/Expired During The Most Recently Completed Fiscal Year</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the most recently completed fiscal year, the 390,000 incentive stock options were granted to Executive Officers, Directors, employees/consultants. &nbsp;The Company has no equity or non-equity incentive plans. &nbsp;250,000 stock options previously granted to Executive Officers and Directors were cancelled, forfeited, or expired un-exercised; and 500,000 stock options previously granted to employees and/or consultants were cancelled, forfeited, or expired un-exercised.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
